docs.text:
Access GBIF data


This package offers access to GBIF data, specifically occurrences, and taxonomic information. There are some built-in data-cleaning routines.
docs.title: Home

docs.text: This package offers access to GBIF data, specifically occurrences, and taxonomic information. There are some built-in data-cleaning routines.
docs.title: Access GBIF data

docs.text:
Retrieving occurrences




Getting a single occurrence


#


GBIF.occurrence
 
 
Function
.


Return an interpreted occurrence given its key


source




Getting multiple occurrences


#


GBIF.occurrences
 
 
Function
.


Search for occurrences


This function will return the latest occurrences – usually 20, but this is entirely determined by the server default page size. This is mostly useful to get a few results fast for illustration purposes.


source


Search for occurrences


Returns occurrences that correspond to a filter, given in 
q
 as a dictionary.


source


Note that the 
Occurrences
 type implements all of the iterator methods (
start
, 
next
, 
etc
), so it can be iterated over.




Batch-download of occurences


#


GBIF.next!
 
 
Function
.


Get the next page of results


source


#


GBIF.complete!
 
 
Function
.


Get all pages of results


source
docs.title: Getting data

docs.text: #  GBIF.occurrence     Function .  Return an interpreted occurrence given its key  source
docs.title: Getting a single occurrence

docs.text: #  GBIF.occurrences     Function .  Search for occurrences  This function will return the latest occurrences – usually 20, but this is entirely determined by the server default page size. This is mostly useful to get a few results fast for illustration purposes.  source  Search for occurrences  Returns occurrences that correspond to a filter, given in  q  as a dictionary.  source  Note that the  Occurrences  type implements all of the iterator methods ( start ,  next ,  etc ), so it can be iterated over.
docs.title: Getting multiple occurrences

docs.text: #  GBIF.next!     Function .  Get the next page of results  source  #  GBIF.complete!     Function .  Get all pages of results  source
docs.title: Batch-download of occurences

docs.text:
Filtering observations


Within an 
Occurrences
 object, the occurrences themselves are stored in a view. A view is basically an array that can be masked, so it is possible to retain all of the raw data, while only presenting the data that pass filtering.




Apply filtering to the data


#


GBIF.qualitycontrol!
 
 
Function
.


Cleans a search output


UPDATE


source




List of filters


#


GBIF.have_both_coordinates
 
 
Function
.


Both latitude and longitude are present


This filter will only retain occurrences that have 
both
 a latitude and a longitude field.


source


#


GBIF.have_neither_zero_coordinates
 
 
Function
.


Neither latitude nor longitude are 0.0


This filter will only retain occurrences that are 
not
 at the (0,0) coordinate.


source


#


GBIF.have_no_zero_coordinates
 
 
Function
.


At most one of latitude and longitude is 0.0


This filter will only retain occurrences that have 
at most
 one coordinate being exactly 0.0.


source


#


GBIF.have_no_issues
 
 
Function
.


No known issues at all


This filter will retain no observation. At least not in theory, but it is very rare to have GBIF records with absolutely no issues. Its use is discouraged.


By design, it is the default argument for 
qualitycontrol!
 – it's your job to decide precisely which filters you need to use.


source


#


GBIF.have_ok_coordinates
 
 
Function
.


No coordinates issues except rounding and WGS84 assumption


This filter will retain observations that have no issues, with the exception of assuming WGS84 projection (which a large number of GBIF records do), and rounded coordinates (same thing). It is a reasonable filter for most use cases.


source




Making your own filters


Filter functions are all sharing the same declaration: they accept a single 
Occurrence
 object as input, and return a boolean as output. Think of the filter as a question you ask about the occurrence object. Does it have no know issues? If this is 
true
, then we keep this record. If not, we reject it.




Removing filters


#


GBIF.showall!
 
 
Function
.


Show all occurrences


This function reverses the action of 
qualitycontrol!
. It will unmask all records that have been removed under the current filters.


source
docs.title: Filtering records

By design, it is the default argument for  qualitycontrol!  – it's your job to decide precisely which filters you need to use.  source  #  GBIF.have_ok_coordinates     Function .  No coordinates issues except rounding and WGS84 assumption  This filter will retain observations that have no issues, with the exception of assuming WGS84 projection (which a large number of GBIF records do), and rounded coordinates (same thing). It is a reasonable filter for most use cases.  source

Think of the filter as a question you ask about the occurrence object. Does it have no know issues? If this is  true , then we keep this record. If not, we reject it.
